intro: Anemonoides ranunculoides subsp. ranunculoides, commonly known as the meadow anemone, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows in moist meadows, woodlands, and stream banks, preferring well-drained soils. The plant features a basal rosette of heart-shaped leaves with a hairy surface, and it produces clusters of white or pale yellow flowers with five petals. Its flowers are usually 1–2 cm in diameter and bloom in early spring. The subspecies is characterized by its small stature and delicate appearance, making it a common sight in temperate regions.
